tasks.task: Select the best maize variety and create a crop calendar.
subtasks: Choose the appropriate maize variety that matches the local climate.
Consult extension officers in your area for a suitable crop calendar for next season.
Purchase certified seeds from the agro-dealer recommended by Agri-Business Hubs.
Adapt seed maturity timing based on rainfall regions (Agroecological Regions 1, 2A, 2B, and 3).

tasks.task: Test soil acidity and apply lime as needed.
subtasks: Test soil acidity 3-6 months before planting, especially in high rainfall areas.
Apply lime to restore soil pH between 5.5-7, 3 weeks before planting.

tasks.task: Manage crop residue and improve soil fertility.
subtasks: Retain crop residues to help soil retain water and nutrients.
Discuss with community members to improve crop residue management and control grazing.
Utilize cover crops, agroforestry, and livestock manure for soil fertility.
Considergood rainfall areas for planting density (4-5 plants/m2) and low rainfall areas (3-4 plants/m2).
Choose between jab planter (one seed per station) or furrow planting for seed placement.
Determine the appropriate application rates based on soil conditions and field type.
Apply fertilizers 20 cm away from plants and cover to prevent volatilization and runoff.
Adjust urea application schedule based on soil type (all at week 4 for loam, half at week 4 and half at week 7 for sandy).
Monitor fields until week 6 for weed growth.
Use manual methods like hand hoeing or mechanical cultivators for weed removal.
If using herbicides, ensure proper nozzle selection and sprayer calibration by trained staff.
Collect maize by hand or utilize services from the Agribusiness Hubs.
